pred: The GhostVLAD approach is a pooling strategy that was originally proposed for face recognition, but it has been adapted for language identification in this paper. It works by adding ghost clusters to the NetVLAD clusters, which helps to aggregate the model and improve the accuracy of the language identification task.
answers: extension of the NetVLAD, adds Ghost clusters along with the NetVLAD clusters
An extension of NetVLAD which replaces hard assignment-based clustering with soft assignment-based clustering with the additon o fusing Ghost clusters to deal with noisy content.

pred: The ensemble method used in the article works by training multiple models on the same dataset, and then combining their predictions to improve the overall performance. The models are trained on the AS Reader architecture, which uses attention over the document to calculate a blended representation of the answer word. The ensemble method then calculates the attention over each model's context document for every word in the query, and sums the attention for each unique answer candidate. The candidate with the highest sum is selected as the final answer.
answers: simply averaging the predictions from the constituent single models

pred: The authors propose a novel multimodal dual recurrent encoder (MDRE) model that simultaneously utilizes audio and text sequences in recognizing emotions from speech. They use two RNNs to encode data from the audio signal and textual inputs independently. The audio-RNN encodes MFCC features from the audio signal using a recurrent encoder (ARE) and the last hidden state of the audio-RNN is concatenated with the prosodic features to form the final vector representation. The text-RNN encoder (TRE) encodes the speech transcript using a recurrent enc
answers: combines the information from these sources using a feed-forward neural model
encodes the information from audio and text sequences using dual RNNs and then combines the information from these sources using a feed-forward neural model

pred: The new context representation is obtained by splitting the sentence into three disjoint regions based on the two relation arguments, and then using two independent convolutional and max-pooling layers to process each region. The resulting context is then concatenated to form the sentence representation.
answers: They use two independent convolutional and max-pooling layers on (1) a combination of the left context, the left entity and the middle context; and (2) a combination of the middle context, the right entity and the right context. They concatenated the two results after pooling to get the new context representation.

pred:
The baselines mentioned in the article are:

1. Vanilla ST baseline: A model trained from scratch on the ST-TED corpus.
2. Pre-training baselines:
a. Encoder pre-training: The ST encoder is initialized from an ASR model.
b. Decoder pre-training: The ST decoder is initialized from an MT model.
c. Encoder-decoder pre-training: Both the encoder and decoder are pre-trained.
3. Multi-task baselines:
a. One-to-many setting:
answers: Vanilla ST baseline, encoder pre-training, in which the ST encoder is initialized from an ASR model, decoder pre-training, in which the ST decoder is initialized from an MT model, encoder-decoder pre-training, where both the encoder and decoder are pre-trained, many-to-many multi-task model where the encoders and decoders are derived from pre-trained ASR and MT models, Triangle+pre-train: BIBREF18 DBLP:conf/naacl/AnastasopoulosC18 proposed a triangle multi-task strategy for speech translation
Vanilla ST baseline, Pre-training baselines, Multi-task baselines, Many-to-many+pre-training, Triangle+pre-train

Vanilla ST baseline: The vanilla ST BIBREF9 has only a speech encoder and a decoder. It is trained from scratch on the ST-TED corpus.

Pre-training baselines: We conduct three pre-training baseline experiments: 1) encoder pre-training, in which the ST encoder is initialized from an ASR model; 2) decoder pre-training, in which the ST decoder is initialized from an MT model; and 3) encoder-decoder pre-training, where both the encoder and decoder are pre-trained. The ASR model has the same architecture with vanilla ST model, trained on the mixture of ST-TED and TED-LIUM2 corpus. The MT model has a text encoder and decoder with the same architecture of which in TCEN. It is first trained on WMT data (out-of-domain) and then fine-tuned on in-domain data.

Multi-task baselines: We also conduct three multi-task baseline experiments including one-to-many setting, many-to-one setting, and many-to-many setting. In the first two settings, we train the model with $\alpha _{st}=0.75$ while $\alpha _{asr}=0.25$ or $\alpha _{mt}=0.25$. For many-to-many setting, we use $\alpha _{st}=0.6, \alpha _{asr}=0.2$ and $\alpha _{mt}=0.2$.. For MT task, we use only in-domain data.

Many-to-many+pre-training: We train a many-to-many multi-task model where the encoders and decoders are derived from pre-trained ASR and MT models.

pred:
The authors experimented with various summarization algorithms, including:

1. Sentence-based summarization: This approach generates summaries by selecting a single sentence from the given set of sentences.
2. Phrase-based summarization: This approach generates summaries by selecting a set of candidate phrases from the given set of sentences.
3. ILP-based summarization: This approach uses Integer Linear Programming (ILP) to identify a set the selected candidate phrases for the summary.

pred: The weights are dynamically adjusted using a decaying factor, which is multiplied with the soft probability of each example. This factor changes as training proceeds, making the model less focused on easy examples and more attentive to hard-negative examples.
answers: One can think $(1-p_{i1})$ as a weight associated with each example, which changes as training proceeds. The intuition of changing $p_{i1}$ to $(1-p_{i1}) p_{i1}$ is to push down the weight of easy examples. For easy examples whose probability are approaching 0 or 1, $(1-p_{i1}) p_{i1}$ makes the model attach significantly less focus to them. Figure FIGREF23 gives gives an explanation from the perspective in derivative: the derivative of $\frac{(1-p)p}{1+(1-p)p}$ with respect to $p$ approaches 0 immediately after $p$ approaches 0, which means the model attends less to examples once they are correctly classified.
associates each training example with a weight in proportion to $(1-p)$, and this weight dynamically changes as training proceeds

pred: The proposed strategies, KG-A2C-chained and KG-A2C-Explore, are able to pass the bottleneck in Zork1 at a score of 40, where the player is eaten by a "grue" if they do not first light a lamp. The lamp must be lit many steps after first being encountered, in a different section of the game, to continue exploring.

pred: Masking words in the decoder is helpful because it provides a more complete input sequence, which is consistent with the pre-training process of BERT or other contextualized embeddings. This process works as follows: first, the draft decoder writes a summary draft based on a document, and then the refine decoder edits the draft. It concentrates on one word at a time, based on the source document as well as other words. This process helps the decoder learn more fluent and natural sequences, ultimately improving the quality of the generated summaries.
answers: ecause this process is similar to the cloze task in BERT's pre-train process, therefore by using the ability of the contextual language model the decoder can generate more fluent and natural sequences.

Instead, it discusses the authors' model and its performance in relation to other existing systems that address pun detection and location tasks separately. These systems include CRF, BiLSTM, and a rule-based system for pun location. The article also mentions aims to combine pun detection and location tasks as a single sequence labeling problem, which is a novel approach.
answers: They compare with the following models: by Pedersen (2017), by Pramanick and Das (2017), by Mikhalkova and Karyakin (2017),  by Vadehra (2017), Indurthi and Oota (2017), by Vechtomova (2017), by (Cai et al., 2018), and CRF.

pred: The political bias of different sources is included in the model by assigning a political bias label to each news outlet, following a procedure described in the article. This label is then used to classify the political bias of the news shared on Twitter, using a standard set of features such as left-biased or right-biased.
answers: By assigning a political bias label to each news article and training only on left-biased or right-biased outlets of both disinformation and mainstream domains

we also account for political biases inherent to different news sources, referring to the procedure proposed in BIBREF2 to label different outlets. Overall we show that we are able to classify credible vs non-credible diffusion networks (and consequently news articles) with high accuracy (AUROC up to 94%), even when accounting for the political bias of sources (and training only on left-biased or right-biased articles). We observe that the layer of mentions alone conveys useful information for the classification, denoting a different usage of this functionality when sharing news belonging to the two news domains. We also show that most discriminative features, which are relative to the breadth and depth of largest cascades in different layers, are the same across the two countries.

pred:
The experiments conducted in the paper are:

1. Automatic evaluation of the models' performance in transforming non-ironic sentences to ironic sentences.
2. Human evaluation of the generated ironic sentences by four annotators.
3. Human evaluation of the models' performance in transforming ironic sentences to non-ironic sentences.
4. Additional experiments on transforming ironic sentences to non-ironic sentences.
answers: Irony Classifier, Sentiment Classifier for Irony, Sentiment Classifier for Non-irony, transformation from ironic sentences to non-ironic sentences

pred: Gaussian-masked directional multi-head attention is a variant of multi-head attention that captures the representation of different directions in a sentence. It works by dividing the input sequence into multiple sub-sequences and then applying multi-head attention to each sub-sequence. The output of each sub-sequence is then combined using a triangular mask, which ensures that the self-attention focuses on different weights. The final output is a combination of the forward and backward information of the sentence, which is used to predict the label of gaps.
answers: pays attentions to adjacent characters and casts a localness relationship between the characters as a fixed Gaussian weight assuming the weight relies on the distance between characters

Gaussian-masked directional attention can be described as a function to map queries and key-value pairs to the representation of input, Gaussian-masked directional attention expects to pay attention to the adjacent characters of each positions and cast the localness relationship between characters as a fix Gaussian weight for attention, Gaussian weight only relys on the distance between characters
